Hi everybody,

I just would like to recommend you the article "Evolution of=
 declarative memory" by Manns and Eichenbaum. 

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov=
/pubmed/16881079

It is basically a review of the hippocampus which emphasi=
zes an evolutionary perspective to understand its functional role. Here is =
a quote:

"[...] we advance the argument that an evolutionary approach is t=
he key to understanding the fundamental functional role of the mammalian hi=
ppocampus. In each mammalian species, a remarkably conserved hippocampus is=
 wrapped in a unique neocortex. The divergent neocortex cloaks the conserve=
d hippocampal function by requiring a species-specific translation of incom=
ing sensory information before it reaches the hippocampus and of retrieved =
associations before they can be reflected in behavior. Thus, results from e=
xperimental animals may appear incompatible with results from humans unless=
 the differences in neocortical organization are taken into account. Accord=
ing to this view, the kind of information processed by cortical areas may d=
iffer among species, but the intrinsic computations of the hippocampal syst=
em are conserved. Thus, a computational account of hippocampal function can=
 best reveal and characterize hippocampal functional circuitry in a way tha=
t applies equally well across species."

I found this article very inspirin=
g as it illustrates that the hippocampus (which is anatomically very simila=
r across species) is maybe a good starting point to study the relation betw=
een the anatomy ( =3D spatial relations between neurons + their projection =
directions) of a network an its functional role in learning.
